posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
Dear CD ,

Looking for some technical advice from people who might have a better idea than I.

We had a failure on our CANbus this past weekend, where we broke a wire in our “energy chain” going up to the elevator. It was probably due to pinching or maybe too much bending. The wire was simple twisted pair (2 separate wires). We are looking to get some jacketed cable to replace it, possibly chainflex from Igus.

The best looking wire comes as 4 conductor cable. For CAN , we only need 2 wires (we terminate up on the elevator), so that raises my question: would it be better to crimp the wires in pairs (2 wires in parallel), or stick with 1 wires each, and have the 2nd set as a backup?

A couple of things I have thought of:

if they are crimped as 2 pairs of 2 wires, it would be “instantly” redundant (assuming only 1 wire breaks). This could save a match.

OTOH, a broken wire in a crimp pair will still cause signal reflections, and maybe that will cause hard-to-diagnose issues on the CAN bus.

I don’t know how sensitive CAN is to these issues, esp on FRC robots with only a few devices and moderately short runs.

Anyone have a good feel for this?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
I doubt you over-cycled a wire properly contained in an energy chain in a single FRC season, unless you are doing 100x more drive practice than a typical team.

In your situation, I’d be inclined to terminate the wires as two independent twisted pair runs (assuming you buy a cable assembly with two twisted pairs), allowing for the possibility of a rapid switch from one to the other in the pits.

Then decide if you wanted to combine those into parallel runs outside of the terminations, perhaps doing an experiment to see what happens if you only connect one half of one of the pairs and leave the other wire unconnected. (My suspicion is that it will work just fine at 1 Mbps CAN , but testing beats guessing.)

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
CAN is sensitive to electrical noise, and relays on certain electromagnetic interactions between signal+ and signal- that make twisted pair a requirement.

Are the conductors in your selected cable twisted pairs?

Besides a single pair of parallel wires NOT TWISTED being problematic, putting them in parallel with another non-twisted-pair although appearing redundant makes signal integrity even worse with the mutual coupling of the parallel wires. Basically the fairly fast transitions on rising and falling edges of the signal being transfered are going to round off and may be missed as data in the CAN frame.

All of that to say - make sure you are using twisted pairs.

Parallel twisted pairs may not be terrible, but parallel straight wires is going to cause you grief on this longer run through an IGUS chain.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked: The cable we are looking at is 4 conductor twisted wires with braided shielding. Technically, I guess it could be called “shielded twisted quad”, but we would only be using it as a single pair cable (ie not running the bus back through the same cable), so in fact it should pick up less noise than the typical unshielded wire everyone uses (including us).

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: We used Ethernet (Cat6) cable for our elevator CAN . Each of the colored pairs (orange + orange/white, brown + brown/white, green + green/white, blue + blue/white) is a separate twisted pair. I know there are some designations of cable that are designed for repeated flexing, but I can’t remember what those are off the top of my head.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
The wire that broke was 22 AWG silicone “flex” wire.

I did not see it myself. It was in the middle of the chain, and there probably was an element of it getting pulled out from lying smooth, maybe getting pinched, etc. So definitely, the first order affect would be having something jacketed so that the wires have a harder time separating and getting pinched. The power wires do not seem to have such an issue.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: I think Ethernet patch cables are usually stranded, while spooled building wire Ethernet is usually solid.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: In the past we had issues with Ethernet wire in our elevator breaking. Both solid and stranded. We are currently using a Hi-flex cable sold by Automation Direct with no issues. The same Automation Direct that has a $50 voucher in the KOP .
while i think it is overkill, i will say that igus chainflex stuff is both premium and indestructible
WCP sells jacketed CAN , which might just be the easiest option to prevent future issues: 22AWG CAN Wire (Jacketed, 25-feet) – WestCoast Products

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: I’d also recommend more robust wire and/or setting things up for quick swapping.  If you create parallel transmission lines, you’ll wind up changing the effective impedance, which could cause reflections, etc.  If this is the roboRIO CAN bus, it might be OK.  This issue can come up in some CAN topologies, which is one reason higher-speed CAN likes a bus topology.

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Do you have a link or product number for the AD cable? Thanks

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: We are using Q5922-1 Quabbin continuous flexing Cat6/6a industrial Ethernet cable, shielded, 4 twisted pairs, 24 AWG, 7-stranded, tinned copper, polyethylene conductor insulation material, TPE jacket, teal https://www.automationdirect.com/adc/shopping/catalog/bulk_wire_-a- cable/data -a-_communication_cable/q5922-1
